dc:description: ACTN1 was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant platelet-type bleeding disorder 15 in 2013 (Kunishima et al., PMID: 23434115). Affected individuals have macrothrombocytopenia and usually have no or only mild bleeding tendency, such as epistaxis. At least 27 unique missense variants have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, segregation data, and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 30 probands in 8 publications (PMIDs: 23434115, 25361813, 26453073, 28562514, 27479822, 24069336, 31064749, 31237726). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 65 additional family members. More case-level evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence has been reached. This gene-disease relationship is supported by functional alteration in patient (PMID: 25361813) and non-patient cells (PMID: 23434115). It is hypothesized that ACTN1 variants induce more stable actin filaments, thereby impairing stretching and leading to shorter and thicker fibers, however the reason why this mild phenotype is limited to platelets while ACTN1 has a ubiquitous expression is currently not well understood. In summary, ACTN1 is definitively associated with autosomal dominant platelet-type bleeding disorder 15.
curationReasonDescription: The Hemostasis Thrombosis GCEP feels confident that the variant spectrum (missense variants with a gain‐of‐function effect, resulting in an increased binding to actin) of this disease is limiting the ability to assign the appropriate score under genetic evidence, and that evidence supporting the pathogenicity of available variants is strong. As such we opt to override the scoring maximum on the missense variant category and consider the genetic evidence at the full value of 12 pt with 1 pt of experimental evidence for at total of 13 pts this gene disease relationship reaches the Definitive classification.

evidence.dc:description: This frameshift variant, Asp531GlyfsTer21, generates a premature stop codon expected to result in NMD. This is the first predicted or proven null variant reported for ACTN1 (all other variants are missense) so may not contribute to disease by the same mechanism. Additionally, there is a lack of phenotypic and demographic information available for this case resulting in the downgraded score.

evidence.rdfs:label: TGP0784
evidence.detectionMethod: Capture baits were designed to target all consensus coding sequences of the ThromboGenomics genes, the first and last 100 bp of introns, 5’ and 3’ UTRs, regions 1,000bp upstream of the transcription start site and the position of known pathogenic variants.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The patient was sequenced with the ThromboGenomics  HTS panel V3 which includes 96  genes associated with bleeding, thrombotic and platelet disorders.

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Gly764Ser, was supported with evidence of gene impact. Transfecting wild-type constructs into human fibroblasts, the cytoskeleton was organized in filaments, with ACTN1 colocalizing with actin. In cells expressing this variant ACTN1 it was instead distributed uniformly within the cytoplasm, and actin was no longer organized in filaments. The overall allele frequency in gnomAD is 0.00001193 (0.00005437 in the east asian population).

evidence.rdfs:label: F9 proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: WHO bleeding scores of 0 (1 member); platelet count is 117 ×10^9/L; platelet volume is 14.4 fL, platelet diameter is 3.3 μm
evidence.previousTestingDescription: All individuals underwent inherited thrombocytopenia diagnostic work-up (as described in PMID 15477207) resulting in no certain diagnosis.

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Glu225Lys, occurs at a highly conserved residue in the functional N-terminal actin-binding domain. From PMID: 23434115, expression of the variant in CHO cells showed that the variant protein caused disorganization of the actin filaments, in which ACTN1 colocalized with less fine, shortened actin filaments and unbound ACTN1 was coarsely distributed within the cytoplasm. The overall allele frequency on gnomAD is 0.000003978. This is the second patient scored with this variant apparently arising independently in one Japanese family and one Italian family.

evidence.rdfs:label: F4 II-1
evidence.detectionMethod: whole-exome sequencing was performed in 7 individuals and Sanger sequencing in the remaining 121 probands. Only the c.2305G>A variant was identified by WES, the remaining variants were all Sanger sequencing.

evidence.previousTestingDescription: All individuals underwent inherited thrombocytopenia diagnostic work-up (as described in PMID 15477207) resulting in no certain diagnosis.

evidence.rdfs:label: F10 III-1
evidence.detectionMethod: WES was performed in 7 individuals and Sanger sequencing in the remaining 121 probands.

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Arg46Gln, occurs at a highly conserved residue in the functional N-terminal actin-binding domain. Expression of the variant in COS-7 cells showed that the variant protein caused discrete anomalies of the actin network and less fine ACTN1 distribution in the cytoplasm, while wildtype showed a fine and homogenous distribution of actin filaments in the cytoplasm and co-localized with the actin filaments. This is the second patient scored with this variant apparently arising independently in one Japanese family and one French family.

evidence.rdfs:label: Subject V-II
evidence.detectionMethod: The top candidate gene in the linkage-mapped locus, ACTN1, was PCR amplified over its 22 exons and their immediate flanking sequences, then sequenced.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: platelet count 115 G/l, 4 µm in size (60% increase compared with controls), MK cells contained large granules with a heterogeneous distribution and aspect, and the cytoplasm was disorganized with fewer components.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: To ensure the absence of other clinically relevant mutations or variants in the locus segregating with the phenotype, targeted NGS sequencing was performed on eight affected (V-01, V-02, V-07, V-19, V-22, VI-07, VI-20 and VI-21) and two unaffected (IV-01 and V-09) individuals.

evidence.dc:description: Although data suggest that the ACTN1 mutants alter the cytoskeleton organization, the molecular mechanisms leading to the platelet defects are not yet clear.

Low immature platelet counts and slightly increased serum thrombopoietin levels, in patients compared to controls, indicate that the thrombocytopenia derives from defects of the final phases of megakaryocyte maturation.
evidence.rdfs:label: Bottega_PatientCells

evidence.dc:description: Investigations in mouse megakaryocytes showed that they had defective proplatelet formation and platelet release when expressing ACTN1 mutants. These results are consistent with the macrothrombocytopenia and anisocytosis observed in affected individuals.

Cells transduced with wild-type ACTN1 reorganized the actin cytoskeleton with the development of organized actin filaments, which were circumferential and parallel to the cell periphery. However, the circumferential actin-filament network was less organized in the megakaryocytes transduced with altered ACTN1 than in control cells. The number of proplatelet tips was decreased and the size was increased (and more variable) in the megakaryocytes with variant ACTN1.
evidence.rdfs:label: Proplatelet formation
